content: The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard will not have their pay reduced while performing active service. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" guarantees that federal employees serving in the uniformed services or National Guard will not experience a pay reduction during their active duty. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard will not have a pay reduction during active duty. Amounts payable to employees for a pay period are determined based on civilian employment interruption and reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" guarantees federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard will maintain their pay during active duty. The period of entitlement to reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38 is defined, excluding certain provisions and including specified reporting times. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard maintain their pay during active duty. The entitlement to reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38 is determined without considering specific provisions and includes designated reporting times. Payment to employees under this section is made by their employing agency, using the same appropriation or fund as if they were in a pay status, and ideally at the same time and manner as basic pay if their civilian employment had not been interrupted. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, will establish regulations to implement the provisions of the Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002. Agency heads must work with the Office to ensure that employees' rights under this act are upheld. The Federal Aviation Administration Administrator will also collaborate with the Office to establish procedures for employee protection. The terms 'employee', 'Federal Government', and 'uniformed services' have specific meanings as defined in section 4303 of title 38. The terms 'service in the uniformed services', 'employing agency', and 'basic pay' are defined in section 4303 of title 38. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 55 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. READY RESERVE-NATIONAL GUARD EMPLOYEE CREDIT ADDED TO GENERAL BUSINESS CREDIT. The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to pay periods beginning on or after September 11, 2001. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under section 38 is 50% of the actual compensation amount for the taxable year. The actual compensation amount is the pay for days of qualified active duty. The credit is limited to 12 months and does not apply to days other than work days. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under section 38 is 50% of the actual compensation amount for the taxable year, limited to 12 months. No credit is allowed for days of qualified active duty on days other than work days. Qualified active duty excludes training duty specified in title 10 and title 32 of the United States Code. The term 'qualified active duty' refers to active duty excluding training duty specified in title 10 and title 32 of the United States Code, entitling an employee to reemployment rights, benefits, or a leave of absence under chapter 43 of title 38, and hospitalization incident to such duty. Compensation is defined as any remuneration for employment, whether in cash or in kind. The term 'qualified active duty' entitles an employee to reemployment rights, benefits, or a leave of absence under chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, and hospitalization incident to such duty. Compensation is any remuneration for employment deductible from gross income under section 162(a)(1). A Ready Reserve-National Guard employee is a member of the Ready Reserve or National Guard. The terms 'National Guard' and 'Ready Reserve' are defined in title 10, United States Code. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit is part of the general business credit under the Internal Revenue Code. The terms 'National Guard' and 'Ready Reserve' are defined in title 10, United States Code. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit is added as a new paragraph in the Internal Revenue Code, following a conforming amendment to the table of sections. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit, added to the Internal Revenue Code, applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
